text.p: These are the leading stories in the Turkish press on Thursday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Former prime minister and leftist party leader Bulent Ecevit rebuffs proposal by left-wing Republican People's Party to merge the two parties.
- Ruling Welfare Party helps clear coalition partner Tansu Ciller from charges of raising personal wealth by illegal means.
- Ciller mentions difficulties of being in coalition with Islamist Welfare but says she will not split the alliance and leave the country without a government.
- Scandal grows over German nuclear waste dumped in Turkey.
- Foreign writers will be coming to Istanbul on March 10 in order to support Turkish writers and intellectuals charged with writing and publishing a book called "Freedom of Thought".
- Treasury intervenes in the sell-offs of three banks to asking for an inquiry into those who applied for the tender.
- Economy awaits for the ruling coalition partners to end their disagreements which have blocked business life.
- Dolmabahce Palace in Istanbul gearing up to claim back furniture that was given away to other state-owned estates.
